all_summaries: This paper investigates the impact of bottleneck layers and skip connections on the generalization of linear denoising autoencoders (DAEs), revealing that bottleneck dimensions act as a complementary complexity measure to input dimensionality, while skip connections smooth the test error curve by reducing variance, especially in mildly overparameterized regimes. Theoretical analysis shows that increasing bottleneck dimension reduces bias but increases variance, leading to a bias-variance trade-off, whereas skip connections suppress variance, resulting in more stable generalization. The study extends existing theories to two-layer linear DAEs and derives analytical expressions for generalization error, highlighting the role of skip connections in mitigating variance and improving test performance.
